Award.AwardTitle: RI: Mediuim: Abstraction, Equilibrium Finding, Safe Opponent Exploitation, and Robust Strategies for Imperfect-Information Games

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
While game theory has traditionally been used as a thinking tool to analyze small stylized versions of real situations, this project is developing operational tools for analyzing real large-scale settings in full detail. To ensure true scalability, the techniques will be benchmarked on very-large-scale games of negotiation, auctions, and poker. This work is on a path toward a vision where software agents conduct commerce on behalf of humans, or at least advise them to act more intelligently. This will lead to increased social welfare through better decision making. This will also enable broader and fairer access because it will help put less experienced/educated people/companies on an equal footing with expert market participants. Broader access will, in turn, increase the benefits of (electronic) commerce further, and the benefits will be distributed more fairly across segments of society. The paradigm will also yield a form of increased security because strategies generated by the proposed techniques cannot be taken advantage of (at least not by much and not easily).

The projects particular contributions to computational game theory include the development of (lossless and lossy) game-abstraction methods to allow scale-up to larger 'games' of societal import, techniques for settings with more than two agents, techniques for dealing with less-than-rational opponents robustly, and derivation of worst-case guarantees on approximate solutions via nemesis computation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

In this project we achieved significant results and built leading technologies on several aspects of solvig incomplete-information games. The highlights include the following.

Game abstraction: We developed the first mathematical framework and algorithms for abstracting games (to make them solvable) in a way that provides bounds on solution quality. We also developed the leading practical game abstraction framework.

Equilibrium finding: We developed a distributed version of the counterfactual regret minimization algorithm, and an abstraction algorithm that provides effective abstraction for this purpose. Together they won the AAAI Annual Computer Poker Competition (no-limit Texas Hold’em category), which has become a leading scientific benchmark for evaluating algorithms for solving incomplete-information games.

Reverse mapping: We developed the leading techniques for mapping strategies from the abstract game back into the original game. It has been widely adopted by others as well.

Opponent exploitation: Here we made two main contributions. First, we developed an approach that hybridizes game-theoretic play and opponent exploitation so as to try to achieve the safety of game theory while getting the benefits of being able to achieve weak opponents. Second, it was folk wisdom that one cannot exploit an opponent without opening oneself to exploitation; our recent breakthrough proved that such safe exploitation is possible! We provided a full characterization of when, how, and to what extent safe opponent exploitation is possible, and provided algorithms for carrying it out.

Broader impact:

Incomplete-information games have broad applicability. Applications include from cybersecurity games (something we published on in this project – specifically in wireless network jamming domains), security games (something on which we collaborated during the project – specifically light rail security and freeriding), auctions, negotiation, military settings, and biological applications.
